content: Biggest reason any drilling in any area, it would ease the $700 Billion payout to foreign countries. Even tho two of the largest sources are neighbors, Canada and Mexico. Brazil is totally energy independent producing enough oil and biofuels and hopes to almost double their oil in the next few years selling it to us foreigners. Have to love what they did, tho if we did it, we'd be accused of socialist practices. Well, maybe it's time for that. Regulate the oil intake and enhance the domestic production of crude and bio. Germany, Europe leader in renewable fuels is the leader in wind farms but reliance of biodiesel in their cars. A small group of mechanic in the east US put together a car that would compete with any $100,000 models, goes 0 to 60 in 5 seconds, powered by vegetable oil. Natural gas is here. Hibred engines by Toyota and others. The all electric battery cars rejunvenates overnight, and my favorite, the hydrogen fuel that expells water and powers your home while you're watching Venezuela beating Puerto Rice in the 5th inning. Hey, a triple. Watch it now. ESPN . Did I mention wind. Solar. We've got a lot working for us but it takes some leadership of directing this ship. I really think that if this cheap biofuel came on the market almost overnight a lot of countries would be hurting, not only feeding the flock, but less funding for their belligerent dictators and would be intimidators. Left the runner on third, shiite.

content: quote: Originally posted by Bongo_Fury: quote: It was proven a long time ago that the drilling in ANWR would have zero impact on any wildlife in the area. Got a cite for your claim? This is from ANWR.org "http://www.anwr.org/Technology/Today-s-drilling-leaves-a-small-footprint.php" New oil development technology, developed over 30 years on Alaska's North Slope, will allow companies to tap underground producing reservoirs with a much smaller "footprint" on the surface. When Prudhoe Bay was developed in the 1970's, about 2 % of the surface area over the field, or 5,000 acres, was covered by gravel for roads and drilling and production facility sites. If Prudhoe Bay were developed today, using lessons learned since the 1960's, gravel would cover less than 2,000 acres, a 60 % reduction. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford
quote: Originally posted by Bongo_Fury: quote: It was proven a long time ago that the drilling in ANWR would have zero impact on any wildlife in the area. Got a cite for your claim?

When Prudhoe Bay was developed in the 1970's, about 2 % of the surface area over the field, or 5,000 acres, was covered by gravel for roads and drilling and production facility sites. content: quote: Originally posted by Bongo_Fury: quote: It was proven a long time ago that the drilling in ANWR would have zero impact on any wildlife in the area. Got a cite for your claim? There's hundreds of them, the controversary has been around so many years you can find most anything written on it. I'm sure you can find this quote also. Prudhoe Bay has been cited as nasty, filthy, more waste materials and the pipeline leaks created more diasters, averaging 400 spills a day. The average ecomaniac only accepts what was in the original state of pristine nature. On the other hand,, those that benefit financially says that nature takes it course and the wildlife hasn't suffered and return to the area almost overnight. Most aborigine natives that still live from the land (and sea) is more worried about the heat wave that is predicted than any damage. The biggest claim being Prudhoe produces more air contamination than Washington D C. That is a stretch when considering it being the home of politic's which is nothing but hot air. plus the fact I've spent vacations in D C and the pollution is the far worse than any city I've been in including LA, New York, London, New Orleans, St Louis, Miami etc. Prudhoe would be a paradise compared to D C. No drilling in ANWR but 60 miles away Prudhoe is OK and a little further is the western wilderness of Canada that produces most of the oil we use. Go figure. Colorado, Utah, North Dakota, offshore, Florida, California and Texas. All taboo. No can drill. While the North sea dries up, rigs standing in the Gulf of Mexico been pumping for decades and Venezuela is looking for more help getting their oil from the land and sea and our government says NADA.
quote: Originally posted by Bongo_Fury: quote: It was proven a long time ago that the drilling in ANWR would have zero impact on any wildlife in the area. Got a cite for your claim?
reply: There's hundreds of them, the controversary has been around so many years you can find most anything written on it. I'm sure you can find this quote also. Prudhoe Bay has been cited as nasty, filthy, more waste materials and the pipeline leaks created more diasters, averaging 400 spills a day. The average ecomaniac only accepts what was in the original state of pristine nature. On the other hand,, those that benefit financially says that nature takes it course and the wildlife hasn't suffered and return to the area almost overnight. Most aborigine natives that still live from the land (and sea) is more worried about the heat wave that is predicted than any damage. The biggest claim being Prudhoe produces more air contamination than Washington D C. That is a stretch when considering it being the home of politic's which is nothing but hot air. plus the fact I've spent vacations in D C and the pollution is the far worse than any city I've been in including LA, New York, London, New Orleans, St Louis, Miami etc. Prudhoe would be a paradise compared to D C. No drilling in ANWR but 60 miles away Prudhoe is OK and a little further is the western wilderness of Canada that produces most of the oil we use. Go figure. Colorado, Utah, North Dakota, offshore, Florida, California and Texas. All taboo. No can drill. While the North sea dries up, rigs standing in the Gulf of Mexico been pumping for decades and Venezuela is looking for more help getting their oil from the land and sea and our government says NADA.

'Bout time they opened their jackass eyes to see that sending dollars overseas and eliminating the opportunity for great US jobs is abject stupidity.
title: White House open to directional drilling in ANWR

content: Biggest reason any drilling in any area, it would ease the $700 Billion payout to foreign countries. Even tho two of the largest sources are neighbors, Canada and Mexico. Brazil is totally energy independent producing enough oil and biofuels and hopes to almost double their oil in the next few years selling it to us foreigners. Have to love what they did, tho if we did it, we'd be accused of socialist practices. Well, maybe it's time for that. Regulate the oil intake and enhance the domestic production of crude and bio. Germany, Europe leader in renewable fuels is the leader in wind farms but reliance of biodiesel in their cars. A small group of mechanic in the east US put together a car that would compete with any $100,000 models, goes 0 to 60 in 5 seconds, powered by vegetable oil. Natural gas is here. Hibred engines by Toyota and others. The all electric battery cars rejunvenates overnight, and my favorite, the hydrogen fuel that expells water and powers your home while you're watching Venezuela beating Puerto Rice in the 5th inning. Hey, a triple. Watch it now. ESPN . Did I mention wind. Solar. We've got a lot working for us but it takes some leadership of directing this ship. I really think that if this cheap biofuel came on the market almost overnight a lot of countries would be hurting, not only feeding the flock, but less funding for their belligerent dictators and would be intimidators. Left the runner on third, shiite.

content: quote: Originally posted by Bongo_Fury: quote: It was proven a long time ago that the drilling in ANWR would have zero impact on any wildlife in the area. Got a cite for your claim? This is from ANWR.org "http://www.anwr.org/Technology/Today-s-drilling-leaves-a-small-footprint.php" New oil development technology, developed over 30 years on Alaska's North Slope, will allow companies to tap underground producing reservoirs with a much smaller "footprint" on the surface. When Prudhoe Bay was developed in the 1970's, about 2 % of the surface area over the field, or 5,000 acres, was covered by gravel for roads and drilling and production facility sites. If Prudhoe Bay were developed today, using lessons learned since the 1960's, gravel would cover less than 2,000 acres, a 60 % reduction. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

title: White House open to directional drilling in ANWR

content: quote: Originally posted by Bongo_Fury: quote: It was proven a long time ago that the drilling in ANWR would have zero impact on any wildlife in the area. Got a cite for your claim? There's hundreds of them, the controversary has been around so many years you can find most anything written on it. I'm sure you can find this quote also. Prudhoe Bay has been cited as nasty, filthy, more waste materials and the pipeline leaks created more diasters, averaging 400 spills a day. The average ecomaniac only accepts what was in the original state of pristine nature. On the other hand,, those that benefit financially says that nature takes it course and the wildlife hasn't suffered and return to the area almost overnight. Most aborigine natives that still live from the land (and sea) is more worried about the heat wave that is predicted than any damage. The biggest claim being Prudhoe produces more air contamination than Washington D C. That is a stretch when considering it being the home of politic's which is nothing but hot air. plus the fact I've spent vacations in D C and the pollution is the far worse than any city I've been in including LA, New York, London, New Orleans, St Louis, Miami etc. Prudhoe would be a paradise compared to D C. No drilling in ANWR but 60 miles away Prudhoe is OK and a little further is the western wilderness of Canada that produces most of the oil we use. Go figure. Colorado, Utah, North Dakota, offshore, Florida, California and Texas. All taboo. No can drill. While the North sea dries up, rigs standing in the Gulf of Mexico been pumping for decades and Venezuela is looking for more help getting their oil from the land and sea and our government says NADA.
quote: Originally posted by Bongo_Fury: quote: It was proven a long time ago that the drilling in ANWR would have zero impact on any wildlife in the area. Got a cite for your claim?

Prudhoe Bay has been cited as nasty, filthy, more waste materials and the pipeline leaks created more diasters, averaging 400 spills a day. The average ecomaniac only accepts what was in the original state of pristine nature. On the other hand,, those that benefit financially says that nature takes it course and the wildlife hasn't suffered and return to the area almost overnight. Most aborigine natives that still live from the land (and sea) is more worried about the heat wave that is predicted than any damage. The biggest claim being Prudhoe produces more air contamination than Washington D C. That is a stretch when considering it being the home of politic's which is nothing but hot air. plus the fact I've spent vacations in D C and the pollution is the far worse than any city I've been in including LA, New York, London, New Orleans, St Louis, Miami etc. Prudhoe would be a paradise compared to D C. No drilling in ANWR but 60 miles away Prudhoe is OK and a little further is the western wilderness of Canada that produces most of the oil we use. Go figure. Colorado, Utah, North Dakota, offshore, Florida, California and Texas. All taboo. No can drill. While the North sea dries up, rigs standing in the Gulf of Mexico been pumping for decades and Venezuela is looking for more help getting their oil from the land and sea and our government says NADA.
